title: Authors and Citation
text: Ramesh Ramasamy. Author, maintainer, copyright holder. Mathiyarasi Kulandaivadivel. Contributor. Tamilselvan Arumugam. Contributor.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Ramasamy R (2024). visvaR: Shiny-Based Statistical Solutions Agricultural Research. R package version 1.0.0, https://rameshram96.github.io/visvaR/, https://github.com/rameshram96/visvaR.
code: @Manual{,   title = {visvaR: Shiny-Based Statistical Solutions for Agricultural Research},   author = {Ramesh Ramasamy},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 1.0.0, https://rameshram96.github.io/visvaR/},   url = {https://github.com/rameshram96/visvaR}, }

what: Shiny-Based Statistical Solutions for Agricultural Research
title: Shiny-Based Statistical Solutions for Agricultural Research
text: user-friendly tool statistical analysis agricultural research data like ANOVA, correlation, etc. (package developmental stage, strongly encourage feedback users improve package) Package developed Ramesh R PhD Scholar, Division Plant Physiology ICAR-IARI, New Delhi ramesh.rahu96@gmail.com

title: Shiny-Based Statistical Solutions for Agricultural Research
text: can install development version visvaR GitHub using following command:

title: Shiny-Based Statistical Solutions for Agricultural Research
text: Running code open application browser, can paste import data, analysing data can download results word file.
code: library(visvaR) visvaR:::oneway_crd()        # one factor completely randomized design  visvaR:::oneway_rbd()        # one factor randomized block design  visvaR:::twoway_crd()        # two factor completely randomized design  visvaR:::twoway_rbd()        # two factor randomized block design  visvaR:::correlation_multi() # Correlation of multiple variables

what: Using custom fonts inside the pacakge
title: Shiny-Based Statistical Solutions for Agricultural Research
text: Make sure system fonts imported properly loaded

what: Function to make sure necessary fonts are imported from system — check_extrafont
title: Function to make sure necessary fonts are imported from system — check_extrafont
text: function make sure extrafont package installed properly fonts imported loaded used pacakge

title: Function to make sure necessary fonts are imported from system — check_extrafont
Function to make sure necessary fonts are imported from system — check_extrafont
text: function make sure extrafont package installed properly fonts imported loaded used pacakge use custom fonts, please install extrafont package run extrafont::font_import() extrafont::loadfonts().

what: Run the Shiny App for Correlation Analysis of multiple variables — correlation_multi
title: Run the Shiny App for Correlation Analysis of multiple variables — correlation_multi
text: App allows user import data excel/.csv files clipboard select correlation method download results customization options

title: Run the Shiny App for Correlation Analysis of multiple variables — correlation_multi
Run the Shiny App for Correlation Analysis of multiple variables — correlation_multi
text: function runs local instance Shiny app default web browser. app interface allows users upload data, select analysis methods, download outputs.

title: Run the Shiny App for Correlation Analysis of multiple variables — correlation_multi
text: Shiny app part visvaR package designed correlation analysis user can download report word format also option download correlation plot .png file. use custom fonts, please install extrafont package run extrafont::font_import() extrafont::loadfonts().

title: Run the Shiny App for Correlation Analysis of multiple variables — correlation_multi
text: Wei, T., & Simko, V. (2021). R package 'corrplot': Visualization Correlation Matrix (Version 0.92). Available https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=corrplot. Friendly, M. (2002). Corrgrams: Exploratory displays correlation matrices. American Statistician, 56(4), 316-324.

title: Run the Shiny App for Correlation Analysis of multiple variables — correlation_multi
text: Ramesh Ramasamy Mathiyarsai Kulandaivadivel Tamilselvan Arumugam

title: Run the Shiny App for Correlation Analysis of multiple variables — correlation_multi
code: # Example 1: Basic usage if(interactive()) {   correlation_multi() }  # Example 2: Sample workflow with iris dataset if(interactive()) {   # Prepare sample data   write.csv(iris[, 1:4], "sample_data.csv", row.names = FALSE)    # Launch the app   correlation_multi()    # Instructions for users:   # 1. Click "Choose a file" and select sample_data.csv   # 2. Select correlation method (e.g., "pearson")   # 3. Click "Analyze"   # 4. View results in different tabs   # 5. Download plot or Word report as needed    # Clean up   unlink("sample_data.csv") }  # Example 3: Using clipboard data if(interactive()) {   # Copy this to clipboard:   # Var1,Var2,Var3   # 1,2,3   # 4,5,6   # 7,8,9    correlation_multi()   # Click "Paste from Clipboard" after copying data }

what: Run the Shiny App for performing one-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — oneway_crd
title: Run the Shiny App for performing one-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — oneway_crd
text: App allows user import data excel/.csv files clipboard user can select post-hoc test method download report contains anova results plots

title: Run the Shiny App for performing one-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — oneway_crd
Run the Shiny App for performing one-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — oneway_crd
text: function runs local instance Shiny app default web browser. app interface allows users upload data, select analysis method, download outputs.

title: Run the Shiny App for performing one-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — oneway_crd
text: Shiny app part visvaR package designed analysis variance data completely randomized design (one factor) user can download report word format. analysis variance performed using R's aov() function (Chambers & Hastie, 1992; R Core Team, 2024), implements classical ANOVA methodology developed Fisher (1925).use custom fonts, please install extrafont package run extrafont::font_import() extrafont::loadfonts().

title: Run the Shiny App for performing one-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — oneway_crd
text: Fisher, R. . (1925). Statistical Methods Research Workers. Oliver Boyd, Edinburgh. Scheffe, H. (1959). Analysis Variance. John Wiley & Sons, New York. R Core Team (2024). R: language environment statistical computing. R Foundation Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria. URL https://www.R-project.org/

title: Run the Shiny App for performing one-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — oneway_crd
text: Ramesh Ramasamy Mathiyarsai Kulandaivadivel Tamilselvan Arumugam

title: Run the Shiny App for performing one-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — oneway_crd
code: # Example 1: Basic usage if(interactive()) {   oneway_crd() }  # Example 2: Sample workflow with plant growth experiment if(interactive()) {   # Prepare sample data   plant_data <- data.frame(     Treatment = rep(c("Control", "Low", "Medium", "High"), each = 3),     Replication = rep(1:3, times = 4),     Plant_Height = c(25.3, 24.8, 25.1,  # Control                      27.6, 28.1, 27.9,  # Low                      30.2, 29.8, 30.5,  # Medium                      26.8, 27.2, 26.5), # High     Leaf_Count = c(8, 7, 8,    # Control                    10, 11, 10,  # Low                    12, 13, 12,  # Medium                    9, 8, 9)     # High   )    # Save as Excel file   write.xlsx(plant_data, "plant_data.xlsx")    # Launch the app   oneway_crd()    # Instructions for users:   # 1. Click "Choose .xlsx or .csv" and select plant_data.xlsx   # 2. Select post-hoc test method (e.g., "Tukey HSD")   # 3. Customize plot appearance if desired:   #    - Choose bar color   #    - Select font style   #    - Adjust font size   # 4. Click "Analyze"   # 5. View results in different tabs   # 6. Download Word report    # Clean up   unlink("plant_data.xlsx") }  # Example 3: Using clipboard data if(interactive()) {   # Copy this to clipboard:   # Treatment,Replication,Yield   # Control,1,45.2   # Control,2,44.8   # Control,3,45.5   # Treatment1,1,48.6   # Treatment1,2,49.2   # Treatment1,3,48.9   # Treatment2,1,52.3   # Treatment2,2,51.8   # Treatment2,3,52.7    oneway_crd()   # Click "Use Clipboard Data" after copying data }  # Example 4: Multiple response variables if(interactive()) {   # Create data with multiple responses   multi_response_data <- data.frame(     Treatment = rep(c("Control", "Treatment1", "Treatment2"), each = 4),     Replication = rep(1:4, times = 3),     Height = rnorm(12, mean = c(rep(20,4), rep(25,4), rep(30,4)), sd = 2),     Weight = rnorm(12, mean = c(rep(50,4), rep(60,4), rep(70,4)), sd = 5),     Length = rnorm(12, mean = c(rep(10,4), rep(12,4), rep(15,4)), sd = 1)   )    # Save as Excel file   write.xlsx(multi_response_data, "multi_response.xlsx")    # Launch the app   oneway_crd()    # App will analyze all response variables (Height, Weight, Length)   # and generate separate analyses and plots for each    # Clean up   unlink("multi_response.xlsx") }  # Example 5: Working with data frame in memory if(interactive()) {   # Create data frame   yield_data <- data.frame(     Variety = rep(c("V1", "V2", "V3", "V4"), each = 3),     Replication = rep(1:3, times = 4),     Grain_Yield = c(       4.5, 4.7, 4.6,  # V1       5.2, 5.0, 5.3,  # V2       4.8, 4.9, 4.7,  # V3       5.5, 5.4, 5.6   # V4     )   )    # Save temporarily and analyze   write.xlsx(yield_data, "temp_data.xlsx")   oneway_crd()   unlink("temp_data.xlsx") }

title: Run the Shiny App for performing one-way ANOVA on data from a Randomized block design. — oneway_rbd
text: Ramesh Ramasamy Mathiyarsai Kulandaivadivel Tamilselvan Arumugam

title: Run the Shiny App for performing one-way ANOVA on data from a Randomized block design. — oneway_rbd
code: # Example 1: Basic usage if(interactive()) {   oneway_rbd() }  # Example 2: Sample workflow with plant growth experiment if(interactive()) {   # Prepare sample data   plant_data <- data.frame(     Treatment = rep(c("Control", "Low", "Medium", "High"), each = 3),     Replication = rep(1:3, times = 4),     Plant_Height = c(25.3, 24.8, 25.1,  # Control                      27.6, 28.1, 27.9,  # Low                      30.2, 29.8, 30.5,  # Medium                      26.8, 27.2, 26.5), # High     Leaf_Count = c(8, 7, 8,    # Control                    10, 11, 10,  # Low                    12, 13, 12,  # Medium                    9, 8, 9)     # High   )    # Save as Excel file   write.xlsx(plant_data, "plant_data.xlsx")    # Launch the app   oneway_rbd()    # Instructions for users:   # 1. Click "Choose .xlsx or .csv" and select plant_data.xlsx   # 2. Select post-hoc test method (e.g., "Tukey HSD")   # 3. Customize plot appearance if desired:   #    - Choose bar color   #    - Select font style   #    - Adjust font size   # 4. Click "Analyze"   # 5. View results in different tabs   # 6. Download Word report    # Clean up   unlink("plant_data.xlsx") }  # Example 3: Using clipboard data if(interactive()) {   # Copy this to clipboard:   # Treatment,Replication,Yield   # Control,1,45.2   # Control,2,44.8   # Control,3,45.5   # Treatment1,1,48.6   # Treatment1,2,49.2   # Treatment1,3,48.9   # Treatment2,1,52.3   # Treatment2,2,51.8   # Treatment2,3,52.7    oneway_rbd()   # Click "Use Clipboard Data" after copying data }  # Example 4: Multiple response variables if(interactive()) {   # Create data with multiple responses   multi_response_data <- data.frame(     Treatment = rep(c("Control", "Treatment1", "Treatment2"), each = 4),     Replication = rep(1:4, times = 3),     Height = rnorm(12, mean = c(rep(20,4), rep(25,4), rep(30,4)), sd = 2),     Weight = rnorm(12, mean = c(rep(50,4), rep(60,4), rep(70,4)), sd = 5),     Length = rnorm(12, mean = c(rep(10,4), rep(12,4), rep(15,4)), sd = 1)   )    # Save as Excel file   write.xlsx(multi_response_data, "multi_response.xlsx")    # Launch the app   oneway_rbd()   }

title: Run the Shiny App for performing two-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — twoway_crd
Run the Shiny App for performing two-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — twoway_crd
text: function runs local instance Shiny app default web browser. app interface allows users upload data, select analysis method, download outputs.

title: Run the Shiny App for performing two-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — twoway_crd
text: Shiny app part visvaR package designed analysis variance data completely randomized design (two factor) user can download report word format. analysis variance performed using R's aov() function (Chambers & Hastie, 1992; R Core Team, 2024), implements classical ANOVA methodology developed Fisher (1925). use custom fonts, please install extrafont package run extrafont::font_import() extrafont::loadfonts().

title: Run the Shiny App for performing two-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — twoway_crd
text: Fisher, R. . (1925). Statistical Methods Research Workers. Oliver Boyd, Edinburgh. Scheffe, H. (1959). Analysis Variance. John Wiley & Sons, New York. R Core Team (2024). R: language environment statistical computing. R Foundation Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria. URL https://www.R-project.org/

title: Run the Shiny App for performing two-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — twoway_crd
text: Ramesh Ramasamy Mathiyarsai Kulandaivadivel Tamilselvan Arumugam

title: Run the Shiny App for performing two-way ANOVA on data from a completely randomized design. — twoway_crd
code: # Example 1: Basic usage if(interactive()) {   twoway_crd() }  # Example 2: Sample workflow with factorial fertilizer experiment if(interactive()) {   # Prepare sample data with two factors: Nitrogen and Phosphorus levels   fertilizer_data <- data.frame(     Nitrogen = rep(c("N0", "N30", "N60"), each = 12),     Phosphorus = rep(rep(c("P0", "P30", "P60", "P90"), each = 3), times = 3),     Replication = rep(1:3, times = 12),     Grain_Yield = c(       4.2, 4.0, 4.1,  # N0-P0       4.8, 4.6, 4.7,  # N0-P30       5.1, 5.0, 5.2,  # N0-P60       5.0, 4.9, 5.1,  # N0-P90       5.5, 5.3, 5.4,  # N30-P0       6.2, 6.0, 6.1,  # N30-P30       6.8, 6.6, 6.7,  # N30-P60       6.7, 6.5, 6.6,  # N30-P90       6.0, 5.8, 5.9,  # N60-P0       6.8, 6.6, 6.7,  # N60-P30       7.5, 7.3, 7.4,  # N60-P60       7.4, 7.2, 7.3   # N60-P90     ),     Protein_Content = c(       9.0, 8.8, 8.9,   # N0-P0       9.5, 9.3, 9.4,   # N0-P30       9.8, 9.6, 9.7,   # N0-P60       9.7, 9.5, 9.6,   # N0-P90       10.5, 10.3, 10.4, # N30-P0       11.2, 11.0, 11.1, # N30-P30       11.8, 11.6, 11.7, # N30-P60       11.7, 11.5, 11.6, # N30-P90       12.0, 11.8, 11.9, # N60-P0       12.8, 12.6, 12.7, # N60-P30       13.5, 13.3, 13.4, # N60-P60       13.4, 13.2, 13.3  # N60-P90     )   )    # Save as Excel file   write.xlsx(fertilizer_data, "fertilizer_data.xlsx")    # Launch the app   twoway_crd()    # Instructions for users:   # 1. Click "Choose .xlsx or .csv" and select fertilizer_data.xlsx   # 2. Select post-hoc test method (e.g., "LSD" or "Tukey HSD")   # 3. Customize plot appearance:   #    - Select font style   #    - Adjust font size   # 4. Set output filename   # 5. Click "Analyze"   # 6. View results in different tabs   # 7. Download comprehensive Word report    # Clean up   unlink("fertilizer_data.xlsx") }  # Example 3: Using clipboard data if(interactive()) {   # Copy this to clipboard:   # Temperature,Light,Replication,Growth_Rate,Chlorophyll   # Low,Dark,1,2.1,15.2   # Low,Dark,2,2.0,15.0   # Low,Dark,3,2.2,15.1   # Low,Medium,1,2.8,16.5   # Low,Medium,2,2.7,16.3   # Low,Medium,3,2.9,16.4   # Low,High,1,3.2,17.8   # Low,High,2,3.1,17.6   # Low,High,3,3.3,17.7   # High,Dark,1,2.5,14.8   # High,Dark,2,2.4,14.6   # High,Dark,3,2.6,14.7   # High,Medium,1,3.5,16.2   # High,Medium,2,3.4,16.0   # High,Medium,3,3.6,16.1   # High,High,1,4.2,17.5   # High,High,2,4.1,17.3   # High,High,3,4.3,17.4    twoway_crd()   # Click "Use Clipboard Data" after copying data }  # Example 4: Multiple response variables with variety trial if(interactive()) {   # Create data with multiple responses   variety_trial <- data.frame(     Irrigation = rep(c("Full", "Deficit"), each = 18),     Variety = rep(rep(c("V1", "V2", "V3"), each = 6), times = 2),     Replication = rep(1:6, times = 6),     Yield = rnorm(36, mean = rep(c(5.5, 5.0, 4.8, 4.2, 3.8, 3.5), each = 6), sd = 0.2),     WUE = rnorm(36, mean = rep(c(2.2, 2.4, 2.3, 2.8, 3.0, 2.9), each = 6), sd = 0.1),     Biomass = rnorm(36, mean = rep(c(12.5, 11.8, 11.2, 10.2, 9.8, 9.5), each = 6), sd = 0.5)   )    # Save as Excel file   write.xlsx(variety_trial, "variety_trial.xlsx")    # Launch the app   twoway_crd()    # Clean up   unlink("variety_trial.xlsx") }

Click "Choose .xlsx or .csv" and select fertilizer_data.xlsx   # 2. Select post-hoc test method (e.g., "LSD" or "Tukey HSD")   # 3. Customize plot appearance:   #    - Select font style   #    - Adjust font size   # 4. Set output filename   # 5. Click "Analyze"   # 6. View results in different tabs   # 7. Download comprehensive Word report    # Clean up   unlink("fertilizer_data.xlsx") }  # Example 3: Using clipboard data if(interactive()) {   # Copy this to clipboard:   # Temperature,Light,Replication,Growth_Rate,Chlorophyll   # Low,Dark,1,2.1,15.2   # Low,Dark,2,2.0,15.0   # Low,Dark,3,2.2,15.1   # Low,Medium,1,2.8,16.5   # Low,Medium,2,2.7,16.3   # Low,Medium,3,2.9,16.4   # Low,High,1,3.2,17.8   # Low,High,2,3.1,17.6   # Low,High,3,3.3,17.7   # High,Dark,1,2.5,14.8   # High,Dark,2,2.4,14.6   # High,Dark,3,2.6,14.7   # High,Medium,1,3.5,16.2   # High,Medium,2,3.4,16.0   # High,Medium,3,3.6,16.1   # High,High,1,4.2,17.5   # High,High,2,4.1,17.3   # High,High,3,4.3,17.4    twoway_rbd()   # Click "Use Clipboard Data" after copying data }  # Example 4: Multiple response variables with variety trial if(interactive()) {   # Create data with multiple responses   variety_trial <- data.frame(     Irrigation = rep(c("Full", "Deficit"), each = 18),     Variety = rep(rep(c("V1", "V2", "V3"), each = 6), times = 2),     Replication = rep(1:6, times = 6),     Yield = rnorm(36, mean = rep(c(5.5, 5.0, 4.8, 4.2, 3.8, 3.5), each = 6), sd = 0.2),     WUE = rnorm(36, mean = rep(c(2.2, 2.4, 2.3, 2.8, 3.0, 2.9), each = 6), sd = 0.1),     Biomass = rnorm(36, mean = rep(c(12.5, 11.8, 11.2, 10.2, 9.8, 9.5), each = 6), sd = 0.5)   )    # Save as Excel file   write.xlsx(variety_trial, "variety_trial.xlsx")    # Launch the app   twoway_rbd()    # Clean up   unlink("variety_trial.xlsx") }
